Description: Fragment of the body of a black-and-white mottled amphibolite bowl: with an incised inscription on the exterior surface. On the right is a representation of a standing anthropomorphic deity, holding a wʒs-sceptre and ankh, probably Seth or Ash, with traces of other signs above. To the left of the god is the lower portion of serekh, possibly containing an epithet of Seth. Good condition.
Curator's comments: The deity represented may be either Seth or Ash. See P. Kaplony, 'Die Inschriften der Ägyptischen Frühzeit II (Wiesbaden, 1964), 780-90 (note 673). Compare the inscriptions with those on mud seals, P. Kaplony, 'Die Inschriften der Ägyptischen Frühzeit III (Wiesbaden, 1964), pl. 80, abb. 303-4.
